Award.AwardTitle: Legal Mobilization and Intimate Partner Victimization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
One increasingly important resource for victims of intimate partner violence (IPV) is domestic violence civil protection orders. Using theories of legal mobilization and legal consciousness to guide our analysis, this project is designed to better understand why some victims mobilize the civil court system as a resource by filing for protection orders and, conversely, why some victims do not. Through the use of both quantitative (survey) and qualitative (interview) methods, this study focuses on how victims conceptualize the role of the legal system in regard to the abuse they have experienced, who chooses to use protection orders, why they are used, the perceived costs and benefits of protection orders for victims, and the individual and structural barriers that prevent victims from filing for or receiving orders.

The results of this study will address several gaps in the literature on legal mobilization, legal consciousness, help-seeking behaviors of victims of IPV, and inequalities in access to justice. Much previous research in this area derives samples from victims who have already sought legal interventions and, therefore, cannot address why victims do not ask for help from the legal system. Our sample includes victims who have not filed for protection orders, allowing us to better understand the decision to not file for a protection order. The findings from this project can be used to determine unmet legal needs and barriers to accessing the civil courts, as well as the development of best practice models that can be adopted by policymakers, court personnel, legal advocates, and shelters to facilitate victim access to protection orders. This research will also help in the refinement of coordinated community responses to IPV. Finally, results of the research will be used to identify underserved populations who may need culturally appropriate outreach services to address many of the perceived costs of obtaining protection orders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Domestic violence civil protection orders (POs) have become an increasingly important tool in combating DV and intimate partner violence (IPV) in the United States. This project, Legal Mobilization and Intimate Partner Victimization (NSF grant #1154098), used both quantitative and qualitative methods to better understand how IPV survivors use the civil courts as a resource to become or stay safe from their abusers. Specifically, we analyzed which survivors are most likely to use POs, why they are used, the perceived costs and benefits to filing for and obtaining POs, and barriers that prevent survivors from filing for or receiving POs.

Data and sample

Between June 2012 and December 2014, we collected 740 surveys from adult female survivors residing in 10 participating shelters in the American Southwest. The use of a shelter-based sample allowed for the inclusion of survivors who had never come into contact with the legal system or sought a PO. Surveys were available in English and Spanish,  and a significant proportion of the sample is comprised of survivors who are undocumented (13%), Latina (24%), African-American (19%), Native American (6%), and/or multiracial (11%).

Between February and August 2013, we interviewed 20 legal and DV advocates and an additional 100 adult female survivors residing in shelters about survivor decision-making, as well as their perceptions of and experiences with the civil courts and criminal justice system. Eleven of the survivor interviews were conducted in Spanish; all other interviews were conducted in English.

Analysis

Of those survivors surveyed, only 80% knew what a PO was prior to coming to the shelter and 33% had ever tried to obtain one. Of those who had tried in the past year, 71% were successful. Of those survivors who had not, 61% stated that they knew where to file for one. Fewer than half (42%) thought a PO would be helpful; 45% were afraid to seek an order and 55% believed it would increase the violence.

Survivors who were married, have children under 18, who are United States citizens with non-citizen partners, who had experienced more severe sexual violence, and/or who believed that the police would arrest their abusers if they violated the PO were more likely to have sought a PO. Survivors who were employed and whose abuser was employed were less likely to have sought a PO. Neither age nor race were significantly related to the likelihood of seeking a PO.

Of the survivors interviewed, only 18% currently had a PO and 54% had ever had a PO, even though they were living in a DV shelter at the time of the interview. Many survivors reported that they did not have the time or resources to pursue a PO because they were trying to find stable housing, employment, secure government benefits, and/or arrange child care. Others expressed that POs are “just a piece of paper” that would not stop the abuser from harming them. Finally, survivors were often reluctant to use the legal system because they had negative experiences in the past or feared deportation. Overall, survivors described a deliberate process whereby they assessed the perceived costs and benefits of using the civil courts versus other resources.

Advocates identified several barriers that prevent survivors from filing for or receiving POs. These include child care (70%), transportation (55%), and language assistance (50%); insufficient information about/survivor knowledge of POs and the PO process (65%); fears that the survivor and/or the abuser will be deported (55%); and perceptions that POs are ineffective/will not “stop” abusers (70%).
